name: Harvest management
note: Given that this species is popular in the pet trade, monitoring and non-detriment findings should be conducted.

name: Awareness & communications
note: An awareness that wild populations could be impacted by harvesting for pet traded should be raised.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Improved protection needed to reduce harvesting of non-timber forest products.

name: Awareness & communications
note: An awareness that wild populations could be impacted by harvesting for pet traded should be raised. In addition, chameleons are locally persecuted and this should be discouraged.

name: Site/area management
note: The distribution of this species at present is mainly within a Protected Area, and this area should be maintained into the future to ensure that habitat is available for the long-term survival of this species.

name: Harvest management
note: Given that this species is potentially popular for pet trade, monitoring and non-detriment findings should be conducted.

name: Site/area management
note: Ensure that further encroachment of protected and gazetted forests does not occur.

name: Harvest management
note: Listed as a Class A species under Cameroonian law, affording them full protection and prohibiting them from being slaughtered or captured, except under special permit for scientific research, land/building development, or the protection of persons or their property. The species is still harvested and exported, however, suggesting that collection for the international pet trade should be brought in line with national legislation.

name: Site/area protection
note: Additional protected areas would benefit this species across its range.

name: Trade management
note: This species is endemic to Cameroon, yet animals captured in the wild are traded from Equatorial Guinea. Given the lack of documented trade between Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea, these exports are suspected to represent export of individuals smuggled out of Cameroon. This suspected illicit trade states should be examined and addressed.

name: Site/area management
note: Ensure that further encroachment of protected and gazetted forests does not occur.

name: Site/area protection
note: Additional  protected areas would benefit this species across its range.

name: Harvest management
note: Listed as a Class A species under Cameroonian law, affording them full protection and prohibiting them from being slaughtered or captured, except under special permit for scientific research, land/building development, or the protection of persons or their property. The species is still harvested and exported, however, suggesting that collection for the international pet trade should be brought in line with national legislation.

name: Trade management
note: This species is endemic to Cameroon, yet animals captured in the wild are traded from Equatorial Guinea. Given the lack of documented trade between Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea, these exports are suspected to represent export of individuals smuggled out of Cameroon. This suspected illicit trade states should be examined and addressed.

name: Trade management
note: This species is endemic to Cameroon, yet animals captured in the wild are traded in large numbers from Equatorial Guinea. Given the lack of documented trade between Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea, these exports are suspected to represent export of individuals smuggled out of Cameroon. This suspected illicit trade states should be examined and addressed.

name: Harvest management
note: Listed as a Class A species under Cameroonian law, affording them full protection and prohibiting them from being slaughtered or captured, except under special permit for scientific research, land/building development, or the protection of persons or their property. The species is still harvested and exported, however, suggesting that collection for the international pet trade should be brought in line with national legislation.

name: Site/area protection
note: Degradation and transformation of existing montane grasslands should be avoided to ensure that this species is not further impacted

name: Harvest management
note: In some localities in Central Africa, e.g., throughout Gabon, this species could be a sustainably harvested resource with the appropriate management and legislation.

name: Reintroduction
note: Reintroduction programs throughout West Africa are considered critical priority and necessary action to prevent regional extinction.

name: Site/area protection
note: Populations of this species in West Africa and in certain portions of its range in Central Africa that are as yet protected should be identified and at least species-specific protection measures implemented.

name: Training
note: The biodiversity focus of Central and West Africa has largely been on terrestrial ecosystems and large terrestrial vertebrates (e.g., apes and elephants).  As a result, and despite recent CSG initiatives, there are very few local crocodilian biologists or specialists capable of assessing, monitoring and managing local crocodile populations.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: This species will fall victim to ever diminishing prey and breeding habitat resources, especially in West Africa, if fishing and forestry regulations are not drafted and enforced.

name: National level
note: This species is listed as integrally protected in national legislative mechanisms in virtually every country it is known to occur though these laws are not enforced.

name: Site/area management
note: If the forest can receive formal protection, it would also need management at the local level.

name: Site/area protection
note: The forest where this species occurs is not protected.

name: Captive breeding/artificial propagation
note: If the forest destruction cannot be controlled, the species would likely go extinct. If the situation becomes critical, ex situ breeding should be considered.

name: Species recovery
note: The remaining population may remain stable, if further forest is not lost.

name: Awareness & communications
note: There needs to be an awareness within the local community regarding the consequences around the loss of ecosystem services.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: The forest where this species occurs is heavily impacted due to alteration of the habitat for subsistence agriculture. The forest is a resource for ecosystem services and its' loss will not benefit the local community.

name: Linked enterprises & livelihood alternatives
note: Because the primary driver of destruction is subsistence agriculture, it is clear that the local population has no other livelihood to rely upon. A change in their reliance on clearing more landscape for subsistence, could have a positive impact on the rate of destruction.

name: Site/area management
note: If the forest can receive formal protection, it would also need management at the local level.

note: Because the primary driver of destruction is subsistence agriculture, it is clear that the local population has no other livelihood to rely upon. A change in their reliance on clearing more landscape for subsistence, could have a positive impact on the rate of destruction.

note: Work with farmers and land managers to ensure that traditional farming methods are retained, areas of grass are left uncut and in some cases harvest times are delayed8.

name: Conservation payments
note: Use incentives to influence land management practices and habits11.

name: Linked enterprises & livelihood alternatives
note: Encourage well-controlled ecotoursim focussed on this species8.

name: Policies and regulations
note: Prevent the use of pesticides in occupied habitats8.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Increase the area of suitable habitat with protected status.

name: National level
note: Lobby governments in remaining countries where it is not protected, to afford the species legal protection11.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Carry out awareness campaigns concerning the threat from domestic cats8.

name: Site/area management
note: Maximise tree diversity in known habitat.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Control predators around key colonies.

name: Site/area management
note: Manage grazing and other disturbance.

name: National level
note: Ensure implementation of appropriate regulations on pesticides and hunting in key range states.

name: National level
note: Ensure development of appropriate regulations on pesticides and hunting in key range states.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Target promotion of low-disturbance agriculture around nesting colonies.

name: Site/area management
note: Control/regulate human-induced burning of grasslands.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Continue education campaigns designed to mitigate bushmeat hunting within the region.

name: Site/area management
note: Improve the protection of nature reserves and national parks where the species occurs.

note: Collar and Butchart (2013) suggested that captive breeding should be considered.

note: Tackle illicit logging through patrols by local rangers.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Increase the area of suitable habitat included in protected areas.

note: Improve the management of existing protected areas to ensure de facto protection.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Protect significant areas of forest at key sites, in both strictly protected areas and community-led multiple use areas.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Conduct awareness programmes to discourage hunting.

name: Site/area protection
note: Identify key strongholds of the species and prevent further habitat degradation in these areas.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Continue and begin awareness campaigns to prevent persecution.

name: Trade management
note: Tanzania has a trade quota of 400/yr but no population estimates. Given the lag period in declines in South Africa, it is important to manage this trade given the scale of take-off.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note:
Maintain sufficient short grass areas, especially in areas of reduced grazing pressure or bush encroachment; either due to land management practices or increasing CO2 level. At the other extreme, manage over-grazing that eliminates substrate food/cover for prey.

Provision of nest boxes to allow for productivity even if natural nest sites have been lost.

name: International level
note: Attempt to reduce the improper use of pesticide and lead ammunition.

name: Non-monetary values
note: This species is culturally important across the range and in places this is the cause of their persistence. This value should be studied, supported and reinvigorated in areas where other beliefs are eroding traditional beliefs.

name: Captive breeding/artificial propagation
note: Collar and Butchart (2013) suggested that captive breeding should be considered.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Develop strategies for restoring larger blocks of natural forest and connecting corridors1.

name: Site/area management
note: Take measures to prevent forest fires4.

name: Site/area protection
note: Protect as many as possible of the remaining forest fragments in the Bamenda Highlands1.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Educate communities about the magnitude of the forest fire problem4.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Facilitate conservation action in collaboration with traditional authorities to limit further habitat degradation4.

name: Site/area protection
note: Increase the area of suitable habitat that has protected status.

name: Site/area management
note: Facilitate conservation action in collaboration with traditional authorities to limit further habitat degradation6.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Protect areas of the species's habitat.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Discourage hunting and irresponsible pesticide use through awareness campaigns.

name: Trade management
note: Develop actions to minimise trade at both national and international levels.

name: Reintroduction
note: Consider the possibility of re-introductions to areas where the species has possibly gone extinct in recent times.

name: Site/area management
note: Direct management of key sites, such as breeding areas, to help improve the viability of subpopulations.

name: Species recovery
note: Source resources for implementing species action plan.

name: Scale unspecified

name: Captive breeding/artificial propagation
note: Collar and Butchart (2013) suggested that captive breeding should be considered.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Discourage hunting and irresponsible pesticide use through awareness campaigns. Also encourage land use practices that would be more beneficial for this species (e.g. discourage cultivation in wetlands).

name: International level
note: Improve species protection and increase enforcement of hunting legislation.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Conduct public awareness campaign regarding its conservation needs, both through ecotourism to areas such as the Okavango delta, and through local grassroots environmental education7.

note: Control the spread of Salvinia13.

name: Private sector standards & codes
note: Encourage tourist guides to adopt a code of conduct for visiting breeding sites13.

note: Construct firebreaks around breeding sites13.

name: Awareness & communications

name: Substitution

name: Site/area protection
note: Assign permanent protection to more of the Okavango Delta, especially the northern Panhandle. Assign permanent protection to more of the Okavango Delta, especially the northern Panhandle (S. J. Tyler in litt. 1999), and safeguard other key wetlands through designation as reserves or protected areas (Tyler 2011).

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Incorporate concerns over the damage of nesting sites by elephants into elephant management plans13.

name: Site/area protection
note: Protect breeding sites, and prevent or control development that would reduce the species’s breeding habitat, including the implementation of EIA studies before any development (Tyler 2011).

name: National level
note: Enforce legislation and raise public awareness to curb illegal burning of water-margin vegetation and reed-cutting6.

name: Site/area management
note: Prevent activities that decrease the area of floodplains, e.g. channel clearing, drainage, large-scale water abstraction, damming and construction of weirs13.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Regulate access to sites during the breeding season including community led control.

name: Harvest management
note: Reduce exploitation pressures through public awareness campaigns.

name: National level
note: Prevent development which reduces breeding habitat, including through the use of an EIA process for development.

note: Locate and protect important breeding colonies under national protected area legislation.

note: Reduce exploitation pressures through public awareness campaigns.

name: Site/area management
note:
Ensure that new and fully reconstructed electric lines are safe for birds by design, and modify existing high-risk poles to be safe for birds with the most cost-effective mitigation measures (A. Kovács in litt. 2016).

Maintain ecologically and socially sustainable grazing systems to ensure long-term survival of key prey species.

Continue to establish controlled artificial nest systems where safe nest sites are limited to increase breeding population and breeding success (A. Kovács in litt. 2016).

name: National level
note: Maintain or improve systems of wardening and customs control (including DNA sampling to check provenance of traded birds).

name: International level
note: Improve exportation standards including meeting IATA transportation specifications.

name: International level
note: Enforce CITES regulations, particularly in the Middle East and Asia.

name: Policies and regulations
note:
Improve import regulations, staff capacity and practices (quarantine facilities).

Ensure that legislation is appropriate and effective to prevent overharvest (A. Kovács in litt. 2016).

Review and improve the legal protection of the Saker Falcon where it is necessary to protect it from unintentional or deliberate killing and disturbance where it is considered detrimental (A. Kovács in litt. 2016).

name: Awareness & communications
note:
Implement the SakerGAP through strong stakeholder collaboration within the Saker Falcon Adaptive Management Framework (A. Kovács in litt. 2016)

Raise the awareness of stakeholders about the risks of bird - power line interactions, bird friendly designs, their quality applications and priorities for mitigation (A. Kovács in litt. 2016).

Increase awareness of health and conservation issues among falconers.

name: Site/area protection
note: Bring greater protection (against conversion, degradation and pollution) to key breeding environments (Baumgart 1991, Bailey et al. 2001, Fox 2002, ERWDA 2003).

name: Captive breeding/artificial propagation
note:
The species has been heavily exploited, with some captive breeding to compensate (Riddle and Remple 1994, N. Fox in litt. 2002); more is needed.

Falcon health care and controlled releases/reintroduction may reduce the pressure on wild Saker Falcon populations and thereby play an important role in the recovery of the species (A. Kovács in litt. 2016).

name: Species recovery
note: Maintain or implement programmes of population and habitat management throughout the range.

name: Trade management
note: Develop existing microchipping schemes to help monitor and regulate trade and quantify its effects

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Potentially try to limit or prevent the production of hybrid individuals in captive breeding which, if they escape, could lead to genetic introgression in the wild population (Dixon 2012)

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Protect remaining intertidal habitats across the species's range (including the Yellow Sea) to prevent further habitat loss and degradation (Yang et al. 2011, Anon. 2015), and work with governments along the East Asian – Australasian Flyway to prevent destruction of key migratory staging sites (Anon. 2015).

name: Awareness & communications
note: Raise awareness of the species.

name: Site/area protection
note: Protect remaining intertidal habitats across the species's range (including the Yellow Sea) to prevent further habitat loss and degradation (Yang et al. 2011, Anon. 2015), and work with governments along the East Asian – Australasian Flyway to prevent destruction of key migratory staging sites (Anon. 2015).

name: Policies and regulations
note: Incorporate requirements for this species and others into coastal planning (Anon. 2015).

name: Site/area management
note: Manage important sites to reduce the impact of disturbance (Anon. 2015).

name: Site/area protection
note: Establish suitable sites as nature reserves.

name: Site/area management
note: Work with farmers and land managers to ensure the use of favourable land management.

name: Policies and regulations
note: Initiate changes in agricultural practices through EU and national policies.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Increase the area of suitable habitat with protected status.

name: Site/area protection
note: Protect Rugezi Swamp in Rwanda5.

name: Non-monetary values
note: Sustainable fisheries in the Wadden Sea and other important European estuaries should be promoted.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: By working with governments, protect remaining intertidal habitats across the species's range (including the Yellow Sea) to prevent further habitat loss and degradation (Van Gils and Wiersma 1996, Yang et al. 2011, Threatened Species Scientific Committee 2016).

name: National level
note: Legally protect the species in all range states (Leyrer et al. 2014).

name: Awareness & communications
note: Increase public awareness of the species and highlight the importance of key staging sites (Leyrer et al. 2014).

name: Site/area protection
note: By working with governments, protect remaining intertidal habitats across the species's range (including the Yellow Sea) to prevent further habitat loss and degradation (Van Gils and Wiersma 1996, Yang et al. 2011, Threatened Species Scientific Committee 2016).

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Try to restore or create new areas of suitable habitat (Threatened Species Scientific Committee 2016).

name: Site/area management

name: Site/area protection
note: Protect remaining areas of suitable habitat.

name: Site/area management
note: Manage existing reserves appropriately (prescriptions include raising water tables, low-level use of organic fertiliser, low intensity grazing, late mowing, winter flooding, and prevention of succession to bushy vegetation).

name: Site/area management
note: Ensure that migratory staging posts and winter feeding habitats and roosts are conserved and monitored.

name: Site/area management
note: In Europe, use agri-environment schemes to secure protection and appropriate management of farmland breeding habitat.

name: Conservation payments
note: In Europe, use agri-environment schemes to secure protection and appropriate management of farmland breeding habitat.

note: Prevent a loss of key breeding areas due to abandonment of grasslands and meadows in East Europe and Russian far east.

name: Site/area protection
note: Establish nature reserves on the main breeding sites, and aim to get more key sites designated as Special Protection Areas.

name: Captive breeding/artificial propagation
note: Investigate the potential for using a 'headstarting' approach to increase survival to fledging (J. Gill in litt. 2016)

name: Awareness & communications
note: Engage with governments and local people throughout its migration routes; and collaborate with farmers and hunters, carrying out environmental education and outreach work where appropriate.

name: International level
note: Effectively enforce the EU-wide ban on hunting until there is clear evidence that the population has returned to a favourable conservation status.

name: Site/area protection
note: Ensure protection for key sites for this species.

name: Awareness & communications

name: National level
note: Try to reinstate the moratorium of hunting the species in France.

name: National level

name: Site/area management
note: Promote inclusion of turtle-dove requirements into Protected Area management plans. Promote early controlled burning in the European Turtle-dove's wintering range to prevent wildfires. Develop breeding season guidelines for the suitable management of European Turtle-dove key sites.

name: National level
note: Create guidance for the effective enforcement of hunting regulations and develop training to improve the enforcement of hunting laws.

name: National level
note: Survey national hunting legislation. Ensure the consistency of hunting legislation with harvest management measures. Develop legislation to stop poor hunting tourism practice. Influence legislation (or guidelines) to include European Turtle-dove conservation in the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) processes.

name: International level
note: Include the European Turtle-dove on the EU list of priority species. Develop a set of agreed standards and methodologies across all range states. Ensure all national action plans are coordinated with the International Single Species Action Plan for the European Turtle-dove.

name: Private sector standards & codes
note: Develop, test and implement guidelines on managing habitats at passage and wintering sites. Establish management agreements for specific roosting areas under special interest groups. Ensure national monitoring schemes include specific surveys on the European Turtle-dove. Include the European Turtle-dove in national biodiversity strategies and action plans. Increase capacity in small conservation NGOs.

name: Policies and regulations
note: Develop national conservation strategies for conserving the European Turtle-dove.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Create or maintain seed-rich habitats and suitable nesting habitat. Ensure provision of accessible drinking water. Establish chemical-free areas within important European Turtle-dove areas, including restricting chemical use in Priority Intervention Areas.

name: Market forces
note: Promote good hunting tourism practice in areas where hunting tourism occurs.

name: Harvest management
note: Develop a harvest management modelling framework.

name: Trade management
note: Put in place a temporary hunting moratorium and yearly planning on hunting quotas and seasons.

name: Site/area protection
note: Propose that Natura 2000 sites which host 10 or more breeding pairs are made Special Protection Areas (SPAs). Identify Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) and additional Priority Intervention Areas for the European Turtle-dove.

name: Training
note: Develop and promote European Turtle-dove friendly management in farming systems.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Develop a communications strategy to promote the Action Plan. Promote the European Turtle-dove as a target species for national citizen science projects. Implement a European Turtle-dove-specific Sustainable Hunting Initiative to promote good hunting practice. Promote a zero-tolerance approach to illegal killing and conduct an advocacy campaign to promote the enforcement of hunting legislation. Promote good practice for farmers and develop guidelines to reduce the detrimental impacts of agriculture on European Turtle-doves. Create educational materials for schools to reduce the disturbance of wildlife. Promote good practice guidelines for anyone putting out food or water for birds. Promote best practice across the breeding and wintering grounds. Convene a biannual meeting of expert groups to discuss the progress of the action plan. Create an online workspace to facilitate data sharing and discussion. Convene a working group with a representative to liase with Convention on Migratory Species (CMS), African-Eurasian Migratory Landbirds Action Plan (AEMLAP) and Migrant Landbird Study Group (MLSG). Convene an international European Turtle-dove study group and an international European Turtle-dove sustainable harvest working group.

name: Species recovery
note: Develop and put in place emergency feeding schemes.

name: Site/area management
note: Encourage agro-environmental schemes and biodiversity-friendly farming systems, as well as sustainable resource and habitat management schemes. Conserve existing woodland.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Promote sensitizing campaigns in priority countries to reduce illegal killing. Promote a direct campaign to increase the awareness of local communities regarding the conservation status of the European Roller. Use reporting tools, including on social media, to build citizen science datasets om European Roller distribution, movements and abundance. Establish national and an international European Roller working group to promote information exchange and coordination. Promote collaborative work with African organizations.

name: National level
note: Ensure legal protection of the European Roller in priority countries.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Promote native tree replanting to reverse deforestation.

name: Policies and regulations
note: Implement the measures outlined in CMS Resolution 11.16 on The Prevention of Illegal Killing, Taking and Trade of Migratory Birds. Implement CMS Resolution 11.15 and measures outlined in the CMS Guidelines to Prevent the Risk of Poisoning to Migratory Birds, especially with regard to insecticides and rodenticides particularly harmful to the European Roller. Implement measures outlined in CMS Resolutions 9.7 and 10.19 and the measures outlined in UNEP/CMS/COP11/Doc 23.4.2 Programme of Work on Climate Change and Migratory Species to mitigate the effects of climate change on migratory species.

name: Private sector standards & codes
note: Perform Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs) on wind farm projects along the European Roller's migration routes. Encourage the construction of new medium-voltage transmission lines to incorporate appropriate measures to prevent the electrocution of migrating birds. Encourage the collaboration of electric utility companies and conservation organisations to find ways to reduce the electrocution risk posed to birds.

name: International level
note: Promote international cooperation between enforcement authorities and other stakeholders in the regulation of illegal killing, trapping and catching for keeping as pets.

name: National level
note: Improve law enforcement and compliance with laws, policies and regulations.

name: Formal education
note: Promote scholarships to bring students to European research institutes to raise awareness and increase education.

note:
In Kenya, enforce ban on logging of indigenous trees.

name: Site/area protection
note: Effectively conserve the forests where the species occurs.

name: Site/area management

name: National level
note: Lobby for the banning of Diclofenac for veterinary purposes throughout the species's range, and support the enforcement of this ban where it has been adopted. name: International level
note: Enforce the recent ban on the use of the pharmaceutical drug diclofenac in the Indian Subcontinent.

note: Raise awareness amongst pastoralists of the dangers of using Diclofenac for livestock. Effectively reduce risks of poisoning through strict  education of impacts and laws. In key areas of the species range, implement long term and large-scale education and community involvement program. Raise awareness among risk groups and enforcement authorities against illegal killing. Raise awareness among planners and developers against dangerous energy infrastructure.

name: Training
note: Build capacity in countries along the migration flyways and in the wintering areas.

name: Site/area protection
note: Start and maintain intensive cooperation with local key stake-holders to ensure poison- and poaching-free zones at sites with high densities or congregations of the species throughout the breeding, migration and wintering range, alongside similar efforts for other threatened species.

name: Captive breeding/artificial propagation
note: Confiscate illegally kept live birds and use them for the purposes of captive breeding and future restocking and reintroduction programmes. Ensure a successful ex situ Egyptian Vulture Endangered Species Programme by adhering to best practice and cooperating with the European Endangered Species Programme.

name: Species recovery
note: Establish supplementary feeding sites where appropriate, based on rigorous scientific knowledge and under adaptive management. Where appropriate, guard nests to reduce disturbance.

name: Site/area protection
note: Protect areas of suitable habitat.

name: Site/area management
note: *Implement beneficial forestry policies.

name: Site/area management
note: *Reduce mortality from power-lines.

name: Site/area management
note: *Maintain large trees in open land and protect old slope woodland4.

name: Site/area management
note: *Increase availability of prey species.

name: Scale unspecified
note: *Improve protection of species and sites.

name: Awareness & communications
note: *Raise public awareness.

name: Site/area protection
note: *Improve protection of species and sites.

name: Trade management
note: *Prevent mortality from nest robbing, illegal trade and poisoning.

name: Harvest management
note: *Prevent mortality from nest robbing, illegal trade and poisoning.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Manage existing Special Protection Areas by continuing measures to reduce human disturbance to breeding sites.

name: Site/area management
note: The application of glyphosate-based herbicides to combat and prevent the overgrowth of Typha spp. in wetlands may also benefit the species.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Control of alien predators may be necessary in some areas.

name: Site/area protection
note: Key areas of habitat should be protected from alteration and disturbance.

name: Site/area management
note: Provide suitable breeding structures.

name: Policies and regulations
note: Reduce pesticide use to increase availability of prey for the species.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Water management should be designed to facilitate breeding of the species.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Maintain bare islets with 30-100 % cover of low vegetation (sward heights less than 20 cm) or artificially create some as nesting sites. Offer artificial nesting rafts to promote breeding in areas where there is a lack of suitable nesting habitat or where human disturbance is a particular threat.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Enhance breeding productivity by deterring predatory gulls, either by culling or by the use of non-lethal harassment techniques, e.g. egg and nest destruction, conspicuous human observers, gull displacement walks, and pyrotechnics.

name: Site/area management
note: Use controlled fire to expose the ground surface in areas where vegetation succession is proceeding too far towards closed vegetation stages.

name: Site/area management
note: Encourage vulture feeding sites and the abandonment of livestock carcasses from death by natural causes. Protect and manage breeding sites. Ensure new energy infrastructure is 'vulture-friendly' and modify existing unsafe infrastructure.

name: National level
note: Enforce legislation concerned with incorrect use of poisons and pesticides16.

name: National level
note: Enact legislation against the persecution of the species16.

name: Policies and regulations
note: Limit the hunting of game to improve the availability of carrion. Regulate import, manufacture and sale of poisons.

name: National level
note: Lobby governments to outlaw the sale of Diclofenac for veterinary purposes. Establish legal protection for the species in range states. Legislate and enforce measures to prosecute those involved in illegal killing and trade in vulture species

name: Awareness & communications
note: Raise awareness amongst pastoralists of the dangers of using Diclofenac for livestock27.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Initiate awareness campaigns aimed at farmers, local communities, developers and ecotourists to reduce mortality from persecution, accidental poisoning and disturbance1,5,10,14,16.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Increase awareness amongst farmers of suitable reservoir and drinking trough modification methods16.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Discourage the use of Diclofenac for veterinary purposes in countries where this does not already take place27.

name: Training
note: Improve awareness amongst utilities and NGOs of hazardous pylon designs and suitable measures to prevent collisions through training courses and literature such as posters and best practice manuals16.

name: Site/area protection
note: Provide enforcement for existing nature reserves in West Africa and design of a new one in northern Mali17.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Control and remove non-native plants at breeding sites6.

name: Site/area management
note: Initiate a conservation strategy for the Busia Grasslands that can incorporate development27.

name: Site/area management
note: Consider the burning of grassland patches to prevent shrub and tree encroachment and encourage swarms of insects for the species to feed on27.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Prevent any further significant loss of suitable habitat in South Africa28.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: In Swaziland, increase the area of protected grassland above 1,300 m26.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Raise public awareness of the species's plight and importance of its habitat28.

name: Site/area protection
note: Reduce disturbance by tourists and land-owners.

name: Site/area protection
note: Prevent further loss of grassland habitat in Kenya19.

name: Site/area management
note: Restore habitat.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Protect suitable habitat.
